title: AB 1850
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 13000 of the Education Code is amended to establish the California Civil Liberties Public Education Act, which aims to educate the public about the exclusion and internment of Japanese Americans during World War II. The federal Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians (CWRIC) was created by Congress in 1980 to review Executive Order 9066's impact on American citizens and recommend remedies. The CWRIC issued reports in 1983 based on hearings with over 750 witnesses, including evacuees, government officials, and historians. The federal Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians (CWRIC) concluded that the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II was not justified by military necessity but driven by race prejudice, war hysteria, and a failure of political leadership. President Ronald Reagan signed the federal Civil Liberties Act of 1988, acknowledging the grave personal injustice done to American citizens and resident aliens of Japanese ancestry. The Congress acknowledges the grave injustice done to individuals of Japanese ancestry during World War II, apologizing for the violation of their civil liberties and constitutional rights. The actions were driven by racial prejudice, wartime hysteria, and a failure of political leadership, resulting in significant human suffering. Appropriate compensation has not been made for the damages suffered. The Legislature aims to establish a state test for eligible aliens seeking permanent residency in California under the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. This test would assess their understanding of English, history, and government of the United States to meet federal requirements. The Legislature intends to create a state test for eligible undocumented foreign nationals seeking permanent residency in California under the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. This test would evaluate their knowledge of English, history, and government of the United States to meet federal mandates. The Superintendent, in consultation with the Chancellor of the California Community Colleges, will develop a test to measure the English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government for eligible foreign nationals seeking permanent residency in California under the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. The Governor and other officials will petition for approval to use this test as a requirement for immigration. The Superintendent distributes a test for eligible foreign nationals seeking legal status, to determine educational needs and assess English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government. Test results are confidential and can only be released with written consent for educational purposes. Test results for eligible foreign nationals seeking legal status are confidential and can only be released with written consent for educational purposes. School districts and other eligible agencies receiving federal funds must administer the test with appropriate security measures. Section 52613 of the Education Code is amended to require school districts enrolling nonimmigrant foreign nationals in adult classes to charge a fee covering the full cost of instruction, adopted at least 90 days before classes begin. Section 52651 of the Education Code defines key terms for the chapter, including "Board of Governors," "Chancellor," "Community-based organizations," "Department," and "Educational outreach activities." The Department of Education is defined as the State Department of Education. Educational outreach activities include providing information to temporary resident foreign nationals about federal immigration laws and services available to them, as well as educating newly legalized persons and other immigrants about educational opportunities. The curr_chunk discusses educational opportunities for immigrants, including newly legalized persons. Immigrants are defined as non-US citizens eligible for education in California or naturalized US citizens residing in California. Newly legalized persons are foreign nationals granted temporary resident status or who have obtained permanent resident or citizenship status. Services providers are approved organizations that offer educational services to newly legalized persons. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to education for immigrants, such as "SLIAG" and "Superintendent." It also outlines rules for determining residency, emphasizing the importance of a single residence and the ability to establish one's own residence regardless of marital status. The curr_chunk outlines rules for establishing residence, including the ability for individuals to establish their own residence regardless of marital status or parental guardianship. A foreign national can establish residence unless prohibited by federal law. A foreign national, including an unmarried minor, can establish residence in the United States unless restricted by federal law. An unmarried minor's residence is derived from their parents. Additionally, students meeting specific requirements are exempt from paying nonresident tuition at California State University and Community Colleges. Students meeting specific requirements in California can be exempt from paying nonresident tuition at accredited institutions of higher education. These requirements include earning credits from a California high school equivalent to three or more years of full-time coursework, graduating from a California high school, and registering as an entering student at an accredited institution in California. Additionally, students without lawful immigration status must file an affidavit with the institution stating their intent to legalize their immigration status. Section 69505 of the Education Code in California is amended to exempt income received as reparation payments for Japanese internment during World War II from being considered in determining financial need for applicants. Additionally, students exempt from nonresident tuition may be reported as full-time equivalent students for funding purposes, with confidentiality of student information ensured. Rules and regulations for implementation will be prescribed by the Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges and the Trustees of the California State University. The Education Code in California is amended to exempt reparation payments for Japanese internment during World War II from being considered in determining financial need for applicants. Additionally, certain students exempt from nonresident tuition may be reported as full-time equivalent students for funding purposes. Rules for implementation will be prescribed by the Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges and the Trustees of the California State University. The term "alien" is replaced with "foreign national" for individuals not citizens of the US. "Illegal alien" is replaced with "undocumented foreign national" for those unlawfully present. If the Superintendent of Public Instruction certifies, Section 2 of the act becomes inoperative.
